h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Your provider will instruct you, if necessary, to stop taking medicines that may interfere with the test.
Medicines that can increase 5-HIAA measurements include acetaminophen (Tylenol), acetanilide, phenacetin, glyceryl guaiacolate (found in many cough syrups), methocarbamol, and reserpine.
Medicines that can decrease 5-HIAA measurements include heparin, isoniazid, levodopa, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, methenamine, methyldopa, phenothiazines, and tricyclic antidepressants.
You will be told not to eat certain foods for 3 days before the test. Foods that can interfere with 5-HIAA measurements include plums, pineapples, bananas, eggplant, tomatoes, avocados, and walnuts.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test measures the level of 5-HIAA in the urine. It is often done to detect certain tumors in the digestive tract ( carcinoid tumors ) and to track a person's condition.
The urine test may also be used to diagnose a disorder called systemic mastocytosis and some tumors of the hormone.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The normal range is 2 to 9 mg/24h (10.4 to 46.8 µmol/24h).
Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.
The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Tumors of the endocrine system or carcinoid tumors

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 hours before the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The test provides a rapid and accurate measurement of the amounts of the immunoglobulins IgM, IgG, and IgA.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal results for the three immunoglobulins are:
h2.detail: IgG: 650 to 1600 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or 6.5 to 16.0 grams per liter (g/L)
IgM: 54 to 300 mg/dL, or 540 to 3000 mg/L
IgA: 40 to 350 mg/dL, or 400 to 3500 mg/L
h2.text: The examples above show the common measurements for these test results. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An increased level of IgG may be due to:
h2.detail: Hyperimmunization (higher than normal number of specific antibodies)
IgG multiple myeloma (a type of blood cancer)
h2.text: Decreased levels of IgG may be due to:
h2.detail: Agammaglobulinemia (very low levels of immunoglobulins, a very rare disorder)
h2.text: Increased levels of IgM may be due to:
h2.detail: Waldenström macroglobulinemia (cancer of the white blood cells)
h2.text: Decreased levels of IgM may be due to:
Increased levels of IgA may be due to:
h2.detail: Chronic infections, especially of the gastrointestinal tract
Inflammatory bowel disease, such as Crohn disease
h2.text: Decreased levels of IgA may be due to:
h2.detail: Gut disease that leads to protein loss
h2.text: Other tests are needed to confirm or diagnose any of the conditions above.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.

Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of closed spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Your provider may suggest an "open" MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.
Before the test, tell your provider if you have:
h2.detail: Certain types of artificial heart valves
Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)
Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes)
h2.text: Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:
h2.detail: Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.
Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.
Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.
Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Your provider may order this test if you have:
h2.detail: An abnormal result on a knee x-ray or bone scan
A feeling that your knee is giving away in the knee joint
Buildup of joint fluid behind the knee ( Baker cyst )
Fluid collecting in the knee joint
Knee locking when you walk or moving
Signs of damage to the knee muscle, cartilage, or ligaments
Knee pain that does not get better with treatment
h2.text: You may also have this test to check your progress after knee surgery.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means your knee looks OK.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to a sprain or tear of the ligaments in the knee area.
Abnormal results may also be due to:
h2.detail: Buildup of joint fluid behind the knee ( Baker cyst )
h2.text: Talk to your provider if you have questions or concerns.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Some exams require a special dye, called contrast, to be injected into your body before the test. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.
h2.detail: Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.
Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test to avoid this problem.
Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take extra steps if you are taking this medicine.
h2.text: Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts. Ask about the weight limit before the test if you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms).
You will need to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the CT exam.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: A CT scan can quickly create more detailed pictures of the knee than standard x-rays. The test may be used to detect:
h2.detail: Examine fractures and pattern of fractures
The cause of pain or other problems in the knee joint (usually when MRI can't be done)
Healing problems or scar tissue following surgery
h2.text: A CT scan may also be used to guide a surgeon to the right area during a biopsy .

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Results are considered normal if no problems are seen.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Healing problems or scar tissue after surgery

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Tell your health care provider:
h2.detail: About medicines you are taking, including vitamins and supplements, herbal remedies, and over-the-counter medicines

If you have bleeding problems or if you take blood-thinning medicines such as warfarin (Coumadin), clopidogrel (Plavix), dipyridamole (Persantine), fondaparinux (Arixtra), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), or aspirin
If you are or think you might be pregnant

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Your doctor may order a kidney biopsy if you have:
h2.detail: An unexplained drop in kidney function
Blood in the urine that does not go away
Protein in the urine found during a urine test
A transplanted kidney, which needs to be monitored using a biopsy

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result is when the kidney tissue shows normal structure.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An abnormal result means there are changes in the kidney tissue. This may be due to:
h2.detail: Poor blood flow through the kidney
Connective tissue diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus
Other diseases that may be affecting the kidney, such as diabetes
Kidney transplant rejection , if you had a transplant

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You may have to follow a special diet. Your provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking certain medicines that may affect the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Ketone testing is most often done if you have type 1 diabetes and:
h2.detail: Your blood sugar is higher than 240 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL)
h2.text: Ketone testing may also be done if:
h2.detail: You have an illness such as pneumonia, heart attack, or stroke
Nausea or vomiting that does not go away

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A negative test result is normal.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An abnormal result means you have ketones in your urine. The results are usually listed as small, moderate, or large as follows:
Ketones build up when the body needs to break down fats and fatty acids to use as fuel. This is most likely to occur when the body does not get enough sugar or carbohydrates.

This may be due to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) . DKA is a life-threatening problem that affects people with diabetes. It occurs when the body cannot use sugar (glucose) as a fuel source because there is no insulin or not enough insulin. Fat is used for fuel instead.
An abnormal result may also be due to:
h2.detail: Fasting or starvation: such as with anorexia (an eating disorder)
High protein or low carbohydrate diet
Vomiting over a long period (such as during early pregnancy)
Acute or severe illnesses, such as sepsis or burns
The thyroid gland making too much thyroid hormone ( hyperthyroidism )
Nursing a baby, if the mother does not eat and drink enough

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No preparation is needed.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Ketones are substances produced in the liver when fat cells break down in the blood. This test is used to diagnose ketoacidosis . This is a life-threatening problem that affects people who:
h2.detail: Have diabetes. It occurs when the body cannot use sugar (glucose) as a fuel source because there is no insulin or not enough insulin. Fat is used for fuel instead. When fat breaks down, waste products called ketones build up in the body.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal test result is negative. This means there are no ketones in the blood.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A test result is positive if ketones are found in the blood. This may indicate:
h2.detail: Uncontrolled blood glucose in people with diabetes
h2.text: Other reasons ketones are found in the blood include:
h2.detail: A diet low in carbohydrates can increase ketones.
Glycogen storage disease (condition in which the body can't break down glycogen, a form of sugar that is stored in the liver and muscles)

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Follow the health care provider's instructions on how to prepare for the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test can:
h2.detail: Look for structural changes in chromosomes
h2.text: This test may be done:
h2.detail: On a couple that has a history of miscarriage
To examine any child or baby who has unusual features or developmental delays
h2.text: The bone marrow or blood test can be done to identify the Philadelphia chromosome, which is found in 85% of people with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) .
The amniotic fluid test is done to check a developing baby for chromosome problems.
Your provider may order other tests that go together with a karyotype:
h2.detail: Microarray: Looks at small changes in the chromosomes
Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): Looks for small mistakes such as deletions in the chromosomes

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal results are:
h2.detail: Females: 44 autosomes and 2 sex chromosomes (XX), written as 46, XX
Males: 44 autosomes and 2 sex chromosomes (XY), written as 46, XY

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to a genetic syndrome or condition, such as:
Chemotherapy may cause chromosome breaks that affect normal karyotyping results.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You must sign a consent form. You may be asked to not eat or drink for several hours before the test. You may wish to empty your bladder just before the test.
Tell the provider if you are pregnant or you have bleeding problems. Also mention if you have had an allergic reaction to x-ray contrast material or any iodine-containing substance.

If you are having this test done with sentinel lymph node biopsy (for breast cancer and melanoma), then you will need to prepare for the operating room. A surgeon and anesthesiologist will tell you how to prepare for the procedure.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: A lymphangiogram is used with lymph node biopsy to determine the possible spread of cancer and the effectiveness of cancer therapy.
Contrast dye and x-rays are used to help determine the cause of swelling in an arm or leg and check for diseases that may be caused by parasites.
Additional conditions under which the test may be performed:

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Enlarged lymph nodes ( swollen glands ) that have a foamy appearance may be a sign of lymphatic cancer.

Nodes or parts of the nodes that do not fill with the dye suggest a blockage and may be a sign of cancer spreading through the lymph system. Blockage of the lymph vessels may be caused by tumor , infection, injury, or previous surgery.
Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Your health care provider will instruct you on how to prepare for the lymph node sampling.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Your provider may order this test if you have swollen glands and infection is suspected.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means there was no growth of microorganisms on the lab dish.
Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results are a sign of a bacterial, fungal, or viral infection.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Tell your provider:
h2.detail: If you have any drug allergies
What medicines you are taking (including any supplements or herbal remedies)
h2.text: Your provider may ask you to:
h2.detail: Stop taking any blood thinners, such as aspirin, heparin, warfarin (Coumadin), or clopidogrel (Plavix) 5 to 10 days before the procedure
Not eat or drink anything after a certain period of time before the biopsy
Arrive at a certain time for the procedure
h2.text: You must sign a consent form.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The test is used to diagnose cancer, sarcoidosis, or an infection (such as tuberculosis):
h2.detail: When you or your provider feel swollen glands and they do not go away
When lymph nodes are present on a CT or MRI scan
For some people with breast cancer or melanoma , to see if the cancer has spread (sentinel lymph node biopsy)
h2.text: The results of the biopsy help your provider decide on further tests and treatments.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: If a lymph node biopsy does not show any signs of cancer, it is more likely that other lymph nodes nearby are also cancer-free. This information can help the provider decide about further tests and treatments.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to many different conditions, from very mild infections to cancer.
For example, enlarged lymph nodes may be due to:
h2.detail: Cancer of the lymph tissue ( Hodgkin ) or non-Hodgkin lymphoma
Inflammation of lymph nodes and other organs and tissues ( sarcoidosis )

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Your health care provider will ask you to temporarily stop medicines that may affect the test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. These include:

If you are a woman of childbearing age, the test may need to be done on a specific day of your menstrual cycle. Tell your provider if you have recently been exposed to radioisotopes, such as during a nuclear medicine test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: In women, an increase in LH level at mid-cycle causes release of eggs (ovulation). Your doctor will order this test to see if:
h2.detail: You are ovulating, when you are having trouble getting pregnant or have periods that are not regular
h2.text: If you are a man, the test may be ordered if you have signs of infertility or lowered sex drive. The test may be ordered if you have signs of a pituitary gland problem.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal results for adult women are:
h2.detail: Level peaks even higher around the middle of the menstrual cycle
Level then becomes higher after menopause - 14.2 to 52.3 IU/L
h2.text: LH levels are normally low during childhood.
Normal result for men over 18 years of age is around 1.8 to 8.6 IU/L.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test result.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: In women, a higher than normal level of LH is seen:
h2.detail: When women of childbearing age are not ovulating
When there is an imbalance of female sex hormones (such as with polycystic ovary syndrome )
Turner syndrome (rare genetic condition in which a female does not have the usual pair of 2 X chromosomes)
When the ovaries produce little or no hormones (ovarian hypofunction)
h2.text: In men, a higher than normal level of LH may be due to:
h2.detail: Absence of testes or testes that do not function ( anorchia )
Problem with genes, such as Klinefelter syndrome
Endocrine glands that are overactive or form a tumor ( multiple endocrine neoplasia )
h2.text: In children, a higher than normal level is seen in early ( precocious ) puberty.
A lower than normal level of LH may be due to the pituitary gland not making enough hormone ( hypopituitarism ).

h2.title: Alternative Names
h2.detail: Interstitial cell stimulating hormone - blood test

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Let your doctor know if you are taking any medicines, especially ones for breathing problems. You may have to temporarily stop taking certain medicines before the test.
Wear loose clothes that allow you to breathe comfortably.
Avoid smoking and heavy exercise for 6 hours before the test.
Avoid heavy meals before the test. They can affect your ability to take deep breaths.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The test is done to see how much air you can hold in your lungs during rest. It helps your doctor determine if a lung problem is due to damage to the lung structure, or a loss of the lungs' ability to expand (get bigger as air flows in).
Although this test is the most accurate way to measure how much air you can hold in your lungs, it is not often used because of its technical difficulties.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal results depend on your age, height, weight, ethnic background, and gender.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results point to a problem in the lungs. This problem can be due to a breakdown of the lung structure, a problem with the chest wall and its muscles, or a problem with the lungs being able to expand and contract.
Lung plethysmography will not find the cause of the problem. But it helps the doctor narrow down the list of possible problems.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You may be asked not to eat anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan. You will be able to drink water.
Tell your health care provider if:
h2.detail: You are afraid of tight spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you relax and feel less anxious.
You are pregnant or think you might be pregnant.
You have any allergies to injected dye (contrast).
You take insulin for diabetes. You will need special preparation.
h2.text: Tell your provider about the medicines you are taking. These include ones bought without a prescription. Some medicines can interfere with the test results.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test may be done to:
h2.detail: Help look for lung cancer, when other imaging tests do not give a clear picture
See if lung cancer has spread to other areas of the lungs or body, when deciding on the best treatment
Help determine if a growth in the lungs (seen on a CT scan) is cancerous or not
Determine how well cancer treatment is working

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means the scan did not show any problems in the size, shape, or function of the lungs.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Lung cancer or cancer of another area of the body that has spread to the lungs
Inflammation of the lungs due to other causes
h2.text: Blood sugar or insulin level may affect the test results in people with diabetes.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Several hours to 1 day before the scan, you will get an injection of gallium at the place where the testing will be done.
Just before the scan, remove jewelry, dentures, or other metal objects that can affect the scan. Take off the clothing on the upper half of your body and put on a hospital gown.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is usually done when you have signs of inflammation in the lungs. This is most often due to sarcoidosis or a certain type of pneumonia.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The lungs should appear of normal size and texture, and should take up very little gallium.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: If a large amount of gallium is seen in the lungs, it may mean any of the following problems:
h2.detail: Sarcoidosis (disease in which inflammation occurs in the lungs and other tissues of the body)
Other respiratory infections, most often a type of pneumonia caused by the fungus Pneumocystis jirovecii

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Before taking this test:
h2.detail: Do not eat a heavy meal before the test.
Do not smoke for at least 4 to 6 hours before the test.
If you use a bronchodilator or other inhaled medicines, ask your health care provider whether or not you can use them before the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The test is used to diagnose certain lung diseases, and to monitor the status of people with established lung disease. Repeatedly measuring the diffusing capacity can help determine whether the disease is improving or getting worse.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal test results depend on a person's:
h2.detail: Hemoglobin (the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen) level

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results mean that gases do not move normally across the lung tissues into the blood vessels of the lung. This may be due to lung diseases such as:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Tell the provider if you are pregnant. Take off all jewelry.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Often, the provider will treat a person with low back pain for 4 to 8 weeks before ordering an x-ray.
The most common reason for lumbosacral spine x-ray is to look for the cause of low back pain that:
h2.detail: Does not go away after 4 to 8 weeks
Is present in an older person

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Lumbosacral spine x-rays may show:
h2.detail: Abnormal wear on the cartilage and bones of the lower spine, such as bone spurs and narrowing of the joints between the vertebrae
Cancer (although cancer often cannot be seen on this type of x-ray)
Spondylolisthesis , in which a bone (vertebra) in the lower part of the spine slips out of the proper position onto the bone below it
h2.text: Though some of these findings may be seen on an x-ray, they are not always the cause of back pain.
Many problems in the spine cannot be diagnosed using a lumbosacral x-ray, including:
h2.detail: Spinal stenosis - narrowing of the spinal column

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You should remove all jewelry or other metal objects before the test. This is because they may cause inaccurate and blurry images.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: CT rapidly creates detailed pictures of the body. A CT of the lumbosacral spine can evaluate fractures and changes of the spine, such as those due to arthritis or deformities.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: CT of the lumbosacral spine may reveal the following conditions or diseases:
h2.detail: Cancer that has spread to the spine

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Some exams use a special dye, called contrast that is put into your body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.
Contrast can be given in different ways.
h2.detail: It may be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm.
It may be given as an injection into the space around the spinal cord.
h2.text: If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.
Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to avoid this problem.
If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), find out if the CT machine has a weight limit. Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts.
You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: CT scans rapidly makes detailed pictures of the lower back. The test may be used to look for:
h2.detail: Birth defects of the spine in children
Spine problems when MRI cannot be used
Healing problems or scar tissue following surgery
h2.text: This test can also be used during or after an x-ray of the spinal cord and spinal nerve roots (myelography) or an x-ray of the disk (discography).

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Results are considered normal if no problems are seen in the lumbar region in the images.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Healing or growth of scar tissue after surgery

h2.title: Alternative Names
h2.detail: Computed axial tomography scan - lumbar spine

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.

Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of closed spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Your provider may suggest an "open" MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.
Before the test, tell your provider if you have:
h2.detail: Certain types of artificial heart valves
Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)
Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes)
h2.text: Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:
h2.detail: Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.
Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.
Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.
Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: You may need a lumbar MRI if you have:
h2.detail: Low back or pelvic pain that does not get better after treatment
Leg weakness, numbness, or other symptoms that do not improve or get worse
h2.text: Your provider may also order a lumbar MRI if you have:
h2.detail: Birth defects of the lower spine
Injury or trauma to the lower spine
Low back pain and a history or signs of cancer
Problems controlling or emptying your bladder

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means your spine and nearby nerves look OK.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Most of the time, abnormal results are due to:
h2.detail: Narrowing of the spinal column ( spinal stenosis )
Abnormal wearing on the bones and cartilage in the spine (spondylitis)
h2.text: Other abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Ankylosing spondylitis , a type of arthritis
Fractures of the lower back due to osteoporosis
h2.text: Talk to your provider about your questions and concerns.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You must sign a consent form. You will be asked to remove jewelry, dentures, and other metals that can affect the scanner's functions.
You may need to wear a hospital gown.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The test can provide information about liver and spleen function. It is also used to help confirm other test results.
The most common use for a liver scan is to diagnose a condition called benign focal nodular hyperplasia, or FNH, which causes a non-cancerous mass in the liver.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The liver and spleen should look normal in size, shape, and location. The radioisotope is absorbed evenly.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may indicate:
h2.detail: Focal nodular hyperplasia or adenoma of the liver
Liver disease (such as cirrhosis or hepatitis )

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Tell your provider about:
h2.detail: Medicines you are taking including herbs, supplements, or medicines you bought without a prescription.
h2.text: You must sign a consent form. Blood tests are sometimes done to test your blood's ability to clot. You will be told not to eat or drink anything for the 8 hours before the test.
For infants and children:
The preparation needed for a child depends on the child's age and maturity. Your child's provider will tell you what you can do to prepare your child for this test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The biopsy helps diagnose many liver diseases . The procedure also helps assess the stage (early, advanced) of liver disease. This is especially important in hepatitis B and C infection.
The biopsy also helps detect:
h2.detail: The cause of abnormal levels of liver enzymes that have been found in blood tests
The cause of an unexplained liver enlargement

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The liver tissue is normal.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: The biopsy may reveal a number of liver diseases, including cirrhosis , hepatitis , or infections such as tuberculosis . It may also indicate cancer.
This test also may be performed for:
h2.detail: Alcoholic liver disease (fatty liver, hepatitis, or cirrhosis)

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You will be asked not to eat anything for 12 hours before the test.
DO NOT smoke before the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: High levels of lipoproteins can increase the risk for heart disease. The test is done to check your risk for atherosclerosis , stroke, and heart attack.
It is not yet clear if this measurement leads to improved benefits for patients. Therefore, many insurance companies DO NOT pay for it.

The American Heart Association and American College of Cardiology DO NOT recommend the test for most adults who DO NOT have symptoms. It may be useful for people at higher risk because of a strong family history of cardiovascular disease.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal values are below 30 mg/dL (milligrams per deciliter), or 1.7 mmol/L.
Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.
The example above shows the common measurements for results of these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Higher than normal values of Lp(a) are associated with a high risk for atherosclerosis, stroke, and heart attack.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: DO NOT eat for 8 hours before the test.
Your health care provider may ask you to stop taking medicines that may affect the test, such as:

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done to check for disease of the pancreas, most often acute pancreatitis .
Lipase appears in the blood when the pancreas is damaged.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: In general, normal results are 0 to 160 units per liter (U/L) or 0 to 2.67 microkat/L (µkat/L).
Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your test results.
Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Higher-than-normal levels may be due to:
This test may also be done for familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency .

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Do not smoke for at least 30 minutes before the test. You will be asked to remove all clothing from the arm and leg being tested.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is most often done to check for narrowing or blockages of blood vessels (arteries) in the arms or legs.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: There should be less than a 20 to 30 mm Hg difference in the systolic blood pressure of the leg compared with that of the arm.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Blood vessel changes due to diabetes
h2.text: Other conditions for which the test may be performed:
If you have an abnormal result, you may need to have more testing to find the exact site of the narrowing.

item.title: LH response to GnRH blood test

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is necessary.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: GnRH is a hormone made by the hypothalamus gland. LH is made by the pituitary gland. GnRH causes (stimulates) the pituitary gland to release LH.

This test is used to tell the difference between primary and secondary hypogonadism . Hypogonadism is a condition in which the sex glands make little or no hormones. In men, the sex glands (gonads) are the testes. In women, the sex glands are the ovaries.
Depending on the type of hypogonadism:
h2.detail: Primary hypogonadism starts in the testicle or ovary
Secondary hypogonadism starts in the hypothalamus or pituitary gland
h2.text: This test may also be done to check:

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An increased LH response suggests a problem in the ovaries or testes.
A reduced LH response suggests a problem with the hypothalamus gland or pituitary gland.
Abnormal results may also be due to:
h2.detail: Pituitary gland problems, such as release of too much hormone ( hyperprolactinemia )
Decrease in hormones made by the endocrine glands
Too much iron in the body ( hemochromatosis )
Recent significant weight loss, such as after bariatric surgery
Lack of periods in women ( amenorrhea )

h2.title: Alternative Names
h2.detail: Luteinizing hormone response to gonadotropin-releasing hormone

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special steps are needed to prepare for this test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Leukocyte esterase is a screening test used to detect a substance that suggests there are white blood cells in the urine. This may mean you have a urinary tract infection .
If this test is positive, the urine should be examined under a microscope for white blood cells and other signs that point to an infection.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A negative test result is normal.

The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An abnormal result indicates a possible urinary tract infection.
The following may turn the test abnormal even when you do not have a urinary infection:
h2.detail: Vaginal secretions (such as blood or heavy mucus discharge)
h2.text: The following may turn the test even when you do have an urinary infection:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You need to fast for 8 hours before the test. This means you can't eat or drink anything during the 8 hours.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: LAP is a type of protein called an enzyme. This enzyme is normally found in cells of the liver , bile, blood, urine and the placenta.
Your health care provider may order this test to check if your liver is damaged. Too much LAP is released into your blood when you have a liver tumor or damage to your liver cells.
This test is not done very often. Other tests, such as gamma-glutamyl transferase , are as accurate and easier to get.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal range is:
Normal value ranges may vary slightly. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An abnormal result may be a sign of:
h2.detail: Bile flow from the liver is blocked ( cholestasis )
Liver ischemia (reduced blood flow to the liver)
Use of drugs that are toxic to the liver

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Your provider may tell you to stop taking any medicines that could affect the test. Drugs that can affect the results of this test include estrogen and progesterone. Never stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: You may need this test to see if there is liver damage. It may also be done to check for certain tumors.
This test is only rarely done. Other tests (such as gamma glutamyl transpeptidase) are as accurate and are more easily available.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal values range from 2 to 18 units per 24 hours.
Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.
The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Increased levels of leucine aminopeptidase can be seen in several conditions:
h2.detail: Liver ischemia (reduced blood flow to the liver)

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: People with dermatitis or other skin irritations should have the test performed on an unaffected part of the body.

If your child is to have this test performed, it may be helpful to explain how the test will feel, and even demonstrate on a doll. Explain the reason for the test. Knowing the "how and why" may reduce the anxiety your child feels.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Leprosy is a long-term ( chronic ) and potentially disfiguring infection if left untreated. It is caused by Mycobacterium leprae bacteria.
This test is a research tool that helps classify the different types of leprosy. It is not recommended as the main method to diagnose leprosy.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: People who don't have leprosy will have little or no skin reaction to the antigen. People with a particular type of leprosy, called lepromatous leprosy, will also have no skin reaction to the antigen.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A positive skin reaction may be seen in people with specific forms of leprosy, such as tuberculoid and borderline tuberculoid leprosy. People with lepromatous leprosy will not have a positive skin reaction.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.

Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of closed spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Your provider may suggest an "open" MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.
Before the test, tell your provider if you have:
h2.detail: Certain types of artificial heart valves
Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)
Worked with sheet metal (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes)
h2.text: Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:
h2.detail: Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.
Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.
Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.
Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test provides detailed pictures of parts of the leg that are hard to see clearly on CT scans.
Your provider may order an MRI of the leg if you have:
h2.detail: A mass that can be felt on a physical exam
An abnormal finding on an x-ray or bone scan
Birth defects of the leg, ankle, or foot
Decreased motion of the ankle joint
Pain, swelling, or redness in a leg
Redness or swelling of the ankle joint
Leg pain and a history of cancer
Leg, foot, or ankle pain that does not get better with treatment
Instability of your ankle and foot

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means your leg looks OK.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Tear or rupture of the Achilles tendon in the ankle area
Tumor or cancer in the bone, muscle, or soft tissue
h2.text: Talk to your provider about your questions and concerns.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Some exams use a special dye, called contrast, that is put into your body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.
h2.detail: Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.
Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to avoid this problem.
Before having the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take extra steps before the test if you take this drug.
h2.text: Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts. Find out if the CT machine has a weight limit if you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms).
You will wear a hospital gown during the study. You will need to take off all jewelry.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: CT scan makes detailed pictures of the body very quickly. The test may help look for:
h2.detail: A mass that is felt during a physical exam
The cause of pain or other problems in the foot, ankle, or knee joints (usually when an MRI cannot be done)
Healing problems or scar tissue following surgery
h2.text: A CT scan may also be used to guide a surgeon to the right area during a biopsy .

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Results are considered normal if the leg being examined looks OK.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Blood clot in the leg (deep venous thrombosis)
Damage to the knee, foot, or ankle joint
Healing problems or development of scar tissue after surgery

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You will be told not to eat or drink for 6 to 8 hours before the test. The procedure takes place in the hospital. Some people may need to stay in the hospital the night before the test.
A provider will explain the procedure and its risks. You must sign a consent form for the procedure.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Left heart angiography is performed to assess the blood flow through the left side of the heart.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result shows normal blood flow through the left side of the heart. Blood volumes and pressures are also normal.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: A hole in the heart (ventricular septal defect)
Abnormalities of the left heart valves
An aneurysm of the heart wall
Areas of the heart are not contracting normally
Blood flow problems on the left side of the heart
Weakened pumping function of the left ventricle
h2.text: Coronary angiography may be needed when blockage of the coronary arteries is suspected.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: In most cases, you should not eat or drink for 8 hours before the test. (Your provider may give you different directions.)
The procedure will take place in the hospital. You may be admitted the night before the test, but it is common to come to the hospital the morning of the procedure.
Your provider will explain the procedure and its risks. You must sign a consent form.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The procedure is done to look for:
h2.detail: Heart defects (such as ventricular septal defects )
h2.text: The procedure may also be done to evaluate and possibly repair certain types of heart defects, or to open a narrowed heart valve.
When this procedure is done with coronary angiography , it can open blocked arteries or bypass grafts.
The procedure can also be used to:
h2.detail: Collect blood samples from the heart
Determine pressure and blood flow in the heart’s chambers
Examine the arteries of the heart (coronary angiography)
Take x-ray pictures of the left ventricle (main pumping chamber) of the heart (ventriculography)

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means the heart is normal in:
The normal result also means arteries are normal.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be a sign of cardiac disease or heart defects, including:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is needed.
For children, it may be helpful to explain how the test will feel and why it is done. This may make the child feel less nervous.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is used to screen people at risk for lead poisoning. This may include industrial workers and children who live in urban areas. The test is also used to measure how well treatment for lead poisoning is working. Lead is common in the environment, so it is often found in the body in low levels.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Small amounts of lead in adults are not thought to be harmful. However, even low levels of lead can be dangerous to infants and children. It can cause lead poisoning that leads to problems in mental development.
Adults:
h2.detail: Less than 10 micrograms per deciliter (µg/dL) or 0.48 micromoles per liter (µmol/L) of lead in the blood
h2.text: Children:
h2.detail: Less than 5 µg/dL or 0.24 µmol/L of lead in the blood
h2.text: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: In adults, a blood lead level of 5 µug/dL or 0.24 µumol/L or above is considered elevated. Treatment may be recommended if:
h2.detail: Your blood lead level is greater than 80 µg/dL or 3.86 µmol/L
You have symptoms of lead poisoning and your blood lead level is greater than 40 µg/dL or 1.93 µmol/L
h2.text: In children:
h2.detail: Blood lead level of 5 µg/dL or 0.24 µmol/L or greater requires further testing and monitoring.
The source of lead must be found and removed.
A lead level greater than 45 µg/dL or 2.17 µmol/L in a child's blood most often indicates the need for treatment.
Treatment may be considered with a level as low as 20 µg/dL or 0.97 µmol/L.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: The health care provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking certain medicines before the test.
Drugs that can increase LDH measurements include:
DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: LDH is an enzyme found in many body tissues such as the heart, liver, kidney, skeletal muscle, brain, blood cells, and lungs. When body tissue is damaged, LDH is released into the blood.
The LDH test helps determine the location of tissue damage.
LDH exists in five forms, which differ slightly in structure.
h2.detail: LDH-1 is found primarily in heart muscle and red blood cells.
LDH-2 is concentrated in white blood cells.
LDH-3 is highest in the lung.
LDH-4 is highest in the kidney, placenta, and pancreas.
LDH-5 is highest in the liver and skeletal muscle.
h2.text: All of these can be measured in the blood.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: LDH levels that are higher than normal may suggest:
h2.detail: Intestinal ischemia (blood deficiency) and infarction (tissue death)

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Your health care provider may tell you to limit certain foods or medicines shortly before the test. Follow instructions on how to prepare for the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is a quick way to determine the absence or presence of an antigen or antibody. Your provider will base any treatment decisions, at least in part, on the results of this test.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: If there is an antigen-antibody match, agglutination will occur.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Preparation will depend on the type of laryngoscopy you will have. If the exam will be done under general anesthesia, you may be told not to drink or eat anything for several hours before the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test can help your provider diagnose many conditions involving the throat and voice box. Your provider may recommend this test if you have:
h2.detail: Bad breath that does not go away
Ear pain that does not go away
Feeling that something is stuck in your throat
Long-term upper respiratory problem in a smoker
Mass in the head or neck area with signs of cancer
Throat pain that does not go away
Voice problems that last more than 3 weeks, including hoarseness, weak voice, raspy voice, or no voice
h2.text: A direct laryngoscopy may also be used to:
h2.detail: Remove a sample of tissue in the throat for closer examination under a microscope (biopsy)
Remove an object that is blocking the airway (for example, a swallowed a marble or coin)

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means the throat, voice box, and vocal cords appear normal.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Acid reflux (GERD) , which can cause redness and swelling of the vocal cords
Cancer of the throat or voice box
Polyps (benign lumps) on the voice box
Thinning of the muscle and tissue in the voice box (presbylaryngis)

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You should not eat or do heavy exercise for 8 hours before the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Your health care provider may order these tests if you have signs of lactose intolerance.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The breath test is considered normal if the increase in hydrogen is less than 12 parts per million over your fasting (pre-test) level.

The blood test is considered normal if your glucose level rises more than 30 mg/dL (1.6 mmol/L) within 2 hours of drinking the lactose solution. A rise of 20 to 30 mg/dL (1.1 to 1.6 mmol/L) is inconclusive.
Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.
The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be a sign of lactose intolerance.
A breath test result that shows a rise in hydrogen content of 12 parts per million (ppm) over your pre-test level is considered positive, and means you may have trouble breaking down lactose.
The blood test is considered abnormal if your glucose level rises less than 20 mg/dL (1.1 mmol/L) within 2 hours of drinking the lactose solution.
An abnormal test should be followed by a glucose tolerance test to rule out a problem with the body's ability to absorb glucose.

h2.title: Alternative Names
h2.detail: Hydrogen breath test for lactose tolerance

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: DO NOT exercise for several hours before the test. Exercise can cause a temporary increase in lactic acid levels.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is most often done to diagnose lactic acidosis .

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: 4.5 to 19.8 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) (0.5 to 2.2 millimoles per liter [mmol/L])
Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.
The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results mean that body tissues are not getting enough oxygen.
Conditions that can increase lactic acid levels include:
h2.detail: Not enough blood containing oxygen getting to a certain area of the body
Severe infection that affects the entire body ( sepsis )
Very low levels of oxygen in the blood (hypoxia)

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No specific preparation is necessary.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: LDH is most often measured to check for tissue damage. LDH is in many body tissues, especially the heart, liver, kidney, muscles, brain, blood cells, and lungs.
Other conditions for which the test may be done include:
h2.detail: Low red blood cell count ( anemia )
Cancer, including blood cancer ( leukemia ) or lymph cancer (lymphoma)

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal value range is 105 to 333 international units per liter (IU/L).
Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A higher-than-normal level may indicate:
h2.detail: Muscle weakness and loss of muscle tissue ( muscular dystrophy )
h2.text: If your LDH level is high, your provider may recommend an LDH isoenzymes test to determine the location of any tissue damage.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Myoglobin is a protein in heart and skeletal muscles. When you exercise, your muscles use up available oxygen. Myoglobin has oxygen attached to it, which provides extra oxygen for the muscles to keep up a high level of activity for a longer period.

When muscle is damaged, myoglobin in muscle cells is released into the bloodstream. The kidneys help remove myoglobin from the blood into the urine. When the level of myoglobin is too high, it can damage the kidneys.

This test is ordered when your provider suspects you have muscle damage, such as damage to the heart or skeletal muscle. It may also be ordered if you have acute kidney failure without any clear cause.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal urine sample does not have myoglobin. A normal result is sometimes reported as negative.
Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Disorder that causes muscle weakness and loss of muscle tissue ( muscular dystrophy )
Breakdown of muscle tissue that leads to the release of muscle fiber contents into the blood ( rhabdomyolysis )

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is needed.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Myoglobin is a protein in heart and skeletal muscles. When you exercise, your muscles use up available oxygen. Myoglobin has oxygen attached to it, which provides extra oxygen for the muscles to keep at a high level of activity for a longer period.

When muscle is damaged, myoglobin in muscle cells is released into the bloodstream. The kidneys help remove myoglobin from the blood into the urine. When the level of myoglobin is too high, it can damage the kidneys.
This test is ordered when your health care provider suspects you have muscle damage, such as of the heart or skeletal muscle.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The normal range is 25 to 72 ng/mL (1.28 to 3.67 nmol/L).

Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An increased level of myoglobin may be due to:
h2.detail: Disorder that causes muscle weakness and loss of muscle tissue ( muscular dystrophy )
Breakdown of muscle tissue that leads to the release of muscle fiber contents into the blood ( rhabdomyolysis )

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You will be told not to eat or drink anything for 6 to 8 hours before the test. The procedure takes place in the hospital. Most often, you will be admitted the morning of the procedure, but in some cases, you may need to be admitted the night before.
A provider will explain the procedure and its risks. You must sign a consent form.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This procedure is routinely done after heart transplantation to watch for signs of rejection.
Your provider may also order this procedure if you have signs of:

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means no abnormal heart muscle tissue was discovered. However, it does not necessarily mean your heart is normal because sometimes the biopsy can miss abnormal tissue.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An abnormal result means abnormal tissue was found. This test may reveal the cause of cardiomyopathy. Abnormal tissue may be due to:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Preparation depends on how the test is done. Follow your health care provider's instructions.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Your doctor may order this test if you have signs of tuberculosis or a related infection.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: If there is no disease present, there will be no growth of bacteria in the culture medium.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Mycobacterium tuberculosis or similar bacteria is present in the culture.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is usually needed. If you will have anesthesia, follow instructions on not eating or drinking anything before the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: A muscle biopsy may be done to identify or detect:
h2.detail: Inflammatory diseases of muscle (such as polymyositis or dermatomyositis )
Diseases of the connective tissue and blood vessels (such as polyarteritis nodosa)
Infections that affect the muscles (such as trichinosis or toxoplasmosis )
Inherited muscle disorders such as muscular dystrophy or congenital myopathy
Effects of medicines, toxins, or electrolyte disorders
h2.text: A muscle biopsy may also be done to tell the difference between nerve and muscle disorders.
A muscle that has recently been injured, such as by an EMG needle, or is affected by a pre-existing condition, such as nerve compression, is not a good choice for a biopsy.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means the muscle is normal.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A muscle biopsy can help diagnose the following conditions:
h2.detail: Muscle disease that involves inflammation and a skin rash ( dermatomyositis )
Inherited muscle disorder ( Duchenne muscular dystrophy )
Destruction of the muscle ( myopathic changes )
Disorders that involve inflammation of the blood vessels and affect muscles ( necrotizing vasculitis )
Inflammatory disease causing muscle weakness, swelling tenderness, and tissue damage ( polymyositis )
Nerve problems that affect the muscles
Muscle tissue under the skin (fascia) becomes swollen, inflamed, and thick ( eosinophilic fasciitis )
h2.text: There are additional conditions under which the test may be performed.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.

Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious, or your provider may suggest an open MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.
Before the test, tell your provider if you have:
h2.detail: Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)
Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes)
h2.text: Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:
h2.detail: Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.
Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.
Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.
Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Having MRIs with other imaging methods can often help your provider make a diagnosis.
MRI images taken after a special dye (contrast) is delivered into your body may provide extra information about the blood vessels.
A magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) , is a form of magnetic resonance imaging that creates 3-dimensional pictures of blood vessels. It is often used when traditional angiography cannot be done.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means the body area being studied looks normal.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Results depend on the part of the body being examined and the nature of the problem. Different types of tissues send back different MRI signals. For example, healthy tissue sends back a slightly different signal than cancerous tissue. Consult your provider with any questions and concerns.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is necessary.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The mononucleosis spot test is done when symptoms of mononucleosis are present. Common symptoms include:
h2.detail: Tender lymph nodes along the back of the neck
h2.text: This test looks for antibodies called heterophile antibodies which form in the body during the infection.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A negative test means there were no heterophile antibodies detected. Most of the time this means you do not have infectious mononucleosis.
Sometimes, the test may be negative because it was done too soon (within 1 to 2 weeks) after the illness started. Your health care provider may repeat the test to make sure you do not have mono.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A positive test means heterophile antibodies are present. These are most often a sign of mononucleosis. Your provider will also consider other blood test results and your symptoms. A small number of people with mononucleosis may never have a positive test.
The highest number of antibodies occurs 2 to 5 weeks after mono begins. They may be present for up to 1 year.
In rare cases, the test is positive even though you do not have mono. This is called a false-positive result, and it may occur in people with:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is necessary for this test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: People with diabetes have a high risk of kidney damage. The "filters" in the kidneys, called nephrons, slowly thicken and become scarred over time. The nephrons begin to leak protein into the urine. This kidney damage can also happen years before any diabetes symptoms begin. In the early stages of kidney problems, blood tests may be normal.
If you have diabetes, you should have this test each year. The test checks for signs of early kidney problems .

If this test shows that you are starting to have a kidney problem, you can get treatment before the problem gets worse. People with severe kidney damage may need dialysis. They may eventually need a new kidney ( kidney transplant ).

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normally, albumin stays in the body. There is little or no albumin in the urine sample. Normal albumin levels in the urine are less than 30 mg/24 hours.
Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: If the test finds a high level of albumin in your urine, your doctor may have you repeat the test.
Abnormal results may mean your kidneys are starting to get damaged . But the damage may not yet be bad.
Abnormal results may also be reported as:
You will need more tests to confirm a problem and show how severe the kidney damage may be.
The most common cause of a high level of albumin in the urine is diabetes . Controlling your blood sugar level may lower the albumin level in your urine.
A high albumin level may also occur with:
h2.detail: Some immune and inflammatory disorders affecting the kidney
h2.text: Healthy people may have a higher level of protein in the urine after exercise. People who are dehydrated may also have a higher level.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You will need to sign an informed consent form. You will be asked to wear a hospital gown or loose-fitting clothes. You will need to remove jewelry or metal objects before each scan. Many drugs interfere with the test. Ask your health care provider which of your regular medicines you may need to stop taking before the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done to help diagnose pheochromocytoma. It is done when an abdominal CT scan does not give a definite answer. It is also used to help diagnose neuroblastoma and can be used for carcinoid tumors.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: There are no signs of a tumor.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: The test may be done to:
h2.detail: Detect tumors that are located outside the adrenal tissues

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is necessary.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Methylmalonic acid is a substance produced when proteins, called amino acids, in the body break down.

The health care provider may order this test if there are signs of certain genetic disorders, such as methylmalonic acidemia . Testing for this disorder is often done as part of a newborn screening exam .
This test may also be done with other tests to check for a vitamin B12 deficiency .

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal values are 0.07 to 0.27 micromoles per liter.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A higher than normal value may be due to vitamin B12 deficiency or methylmalonic acidemia.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is required for this test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: There are several types of oxygen-carrying proteins in the blood. One of them is methemoglobin. Normal methemoglobin level in blood are usually 1%. If the level is higher, you can become sick because the protein is not carrying oxygen. This can make your blood look brown instead of red.

Methemoglobinemia has several causes, many of which are genetic (problem with your genes). This test is used to tell the difference between methemoglobinemia caused by the lack of a protein called cytochrome b5 reductase and other types that are passed down through families (inherited). Your doctor will use the results of this test to help determine your treatment.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normally, methylene blue quickly lowers the level of methemoglobin in the blood.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: You may have a rare form of methemoglobinemia if this test does not significantly lower the blood level of methemoglobin.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is necessary.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done to see if you have a toxic level of methanol in your body. You should not drink methanol. However, some people accidentally drink methanol, or drink it on purpose as a substitute for grain alcohol (ethanol).
Methanol can be very poisonous if you eat or drink it in toxic amounts. Methanol poisoning mainly affects the digestive system, nervous system, and eyes.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result is below a toxic cut-off level.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An abnormal result means you may have methanol poisoning.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You should not eat or drink anything for 6 to 8 hours before the test.
You will be asked to wear a hospital gown and sign a consent form for the procedure. Remove jewelry from the area being imaged.
Tell your provider:
h2.detail: If you have ever had any allergic reactions to x-ray contrast material, shellfish, or iodine substances
If you are allergic to any medicines
Which medicines you are taking (including any herbal preparations)
If you have ever had any bleeding problems

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done:
h2.detail: When there are symptoms of a narrowed or blocked blood vessel in the intestines
To find the source of bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract
To find the cause of ongoing abdominal pain and weight loss when no cause can be identified
When other studies do not provide enough information about abnormal growths along the intestinal tract
To look at blood vessel damage after an abdominal injury
h2.text: A mesenteric angiogram may be performed after more sensitive nuclear medicine scans have identified active bleeding. The radiologist can then pinpoint and treat the source.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Results are normal if the examined arteries are normal in appearance.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A common abnormal finding is narrowing and hardening of the arteries that supply the large and small intestine. This is called mesenteric ischemia. The problem occurs when fatty material (plaque) builds up on the walls of your arteries.
Abnormal results may also be due to bleeding in the small and large intestine . This may be caused by:
Other abnormal results may be due to:

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Most tests are divided into sections, each with its own score. The results help show which part of someone's thinking and memory may be affected.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A number of health conditions can affect mental status. The provider will discuss these with you. An abnormal mental status test alone does not diagnose the cause. However, poor performance on such tests can be due to medical illness, brain disease such as dementia, Parkinson disease, or to mental illness.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You must sign an informed consent form. You will not be able to have food or fluid for 8 hours before the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This procedure is done to look at and then biopsy lymph nodes or any other abnormal growths in the front part of the mediastinum, near your chest wall.
h2.detail: The most common reason is to see if lung cancer (or another cancer) has spread to these lymph nodes. This is called staging.
This procedure is also done for certain infections (tuberculosis, sarcoidosis) and autoimmune disorders .

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Biopsies of lymph node tissues are normal and do not show signs of cancer or infection.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal findings may indicate:
h2.detail: The spread of disease from one body part to another

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: DO NOT use deodorant, perfume, powders, or ointments under your arms or on your breasts on the day of the mammogram. These substances may hide the images. Remove all jewelry from your neck and chest area.
Tell your provider and the x-ray technologist if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, or if you've had a breast biopsy.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: When and how often to have a screening mammogram is a choice you must make. Different expert groups do not fully agree on the best timing for this test.
Before having a mammogram, talk to your provider about the pros and cons of having the test. Ask about:
h2.detail: Whether screening decreases your chance of dying from breast cancer
Whether there is any harm from breast cancer screening, such as side effects from testing or overtreatment of cancer when it's discovered
h2.text: Mammography is performed to screen women to detect early breast cancer when it is more likely to be cured. Mammography is generally recommended for:
h2.detail: Women starting at age 40, repeated every 1 to 2 years. (This is not recommended by all expert organizations.)
All women starting at age 50, repeated every 1 to 2 years.
Women with a mother or sister who had breast cancer at a younger age should consider yearly mammograms. They should begin earlier than the age at which their youngest family member was diagnosed.
h2.text: Mammography is also used to:
h2.detail: Follow a woman who has had an abnormal mammogram.
Evaluate a woman who has symptoms of a breast disease. These symptoms may include a lump, nipple discharge, breast pain , dimpling of the skin on the breast, changes of the nipple, or other findings.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Breast tissue that shows no signs of a mass or calcifications is considered normal.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Most abnormal findings on a screening mammogram turn out to be benign (not cancer) or nothing to worry about. New findings or changes must be further evaluated.
A radiology doctor (radiologist) may see the following types of findings on a mammogram:
h2.detail: A well-outlined, regular, clear spot (this is more likely to be a noncancerous condition, such as a cyst)
Dense areas in the breast that can be breast cancer or hide breast cancer
Calcifications, which are caused by tiny deposits of calcium in the breast tissue (most calcifications are not a sign of cancer)
h2.text: At times, the following tests are also needed to further examine mammogram findings:
h2.detail: Additional mammogram views, called magnification or compression views
h2.text: Comparing your current mammogram to your past mammograms helps the radiologist tell whether you had an abnormal finding in the past and whether it has changed.
When mammogram or ultrasound results look suspicious, a biopsy is done to test the tissue and see if it is cancerous. Types of biopsies include:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.

Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Your provider may suggest an "open" MRI. In open MRI, the machine is not as close to the body.
Before the test, tell your provider if you have:
h2.detail: Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)
Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes)
h2.text: Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner. Avoid carrying items such as:
h2.detail: Watches, credit cards, jewelry, and hearing aids
Hairpins, metal zippers, pins, and similar items

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: MRA is used to look at the blood vessels in all parts of the body. The test may be done for the head, heart, abdomen, lungs, kidneys, and legs.
It may be used to diagnose or evaluate conditions such as:
h2.detail: Arterial aneurysm (an abnormal widening or ballooning of a part of an artery due to weakness in the wall of the blood vessel)
Atherosclerosis of the arms or legs
Heart disease, including congenital heart disease
Renal artery stenosis (narrowing of the blood vessels in the kidneys)

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means the blood vessels do not show any signs of narrowing or blockage.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An abnormal result suggests a problem with one or more blood vessels. This may suggest:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is needed.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done when your health care provider suspects you have an abnormal level of magnesium in your blood.
About half of the body's magnesium is found in bone. The other half is found inside cells of body tissues and organs.

Magnesium is needed for many chemical processes in the body. It helps maintain normal muscle and nerve function, and keeps the bones strong. Magnesium is also needed for the heart to function normally and to help regulate blood pressure. Magnesium also helps the body control blood sugar level and helps support the body's defense (immune) system.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The normal range for blood magnesium level is 1.7 to 2.2 mg/dL (0.85 to 1.10 mmol/L).

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A high magnesium level may indicate:
h2.detail: The adrenal glands are not producing enough hormones ( Addison disease )
Loss of kidney function ( chronic renal failure )
Diabetic ketoacidosis, a life-threatening problem in people with diabetes
Producing less urine than usual ( oliguria )
h2.text: A low magnesium level may indicate:
h2.detail: Alcoholism or severe alcohol withdrawal ( delirium tremens )
Treatment to remove waste from the blood ( hemodialysis )
Scarring of the liver and loss of liver function ( cirrhosis )
Adrenal gland produces too much of the hormone aldosterone ( hyperaldosteronism )
Parathyroid glands do not produce enough parathyroid hormone ( hypoparathyroidism )
