h2.text: Your provider may also order this test to:
h2.detail: Determine if nasal polyps have spread beyond the nose area
Identify a mass or tumor, including cancer
Plan sinus surgery or monitor your progress after surgery

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Results are considered normal if the organs and structures being examined are normal in appearance.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Different types of tissues send back different MRI signals. Healthy tissue will send back a slightly different signal than cancerous tissue.
Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Infection in the bones of the sinuses (osteomyelitis)
Infection of the tissues surrounding the eye (orbital cellulitis)
h2.text: Talk to your provider if you have questions and concerns.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: For some tests, you will need to have a special dye, called contrast, to be delivered into the body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.
h2.detail: Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.
Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to safely receive this substance.
Let your provider know if you have kidney problems. Contrast may not be used if this is the case.
Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take extra steps to prepare.
h2.text: If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), find out if the CT machine has a weight limit. Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts.
You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the scan.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: CT rapidly creates detailed pictures of the sinuses. The test may diagnose or detect:
h2.detail: Infection in the bones of the sinuses ( osteomyelitis )
Injury to the face over the sinuses from trauma
The cause of repeated bloody noses ( epistaxis )
h2.text: The results from this test may also help your provider plan for sinus surgery.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Results are considered normal if no problems are seen in the sinuses.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Your health care provider will tell you how to prepare for the exam. You will use an enema to empty your bowels. This is usually done 1 hour before the sigmoidoscopy. Often, a second enema may be recommended. Or, your provider may recommend a liquid laxative the night before.

On the morning of the procedure, you may be asked to fast with the exception of certain medicines. Be sure to discuss this with your provider well in advance. Sometimes, you are asked to follow a clear liquid diet the day before, and sometimes a regular diet is allowed. Again, discuss this with your provider well in advance of your test date.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Your provider may recommend this test to look for the cause of:
h2.detail: Diarrhea , constipation, or other changes in bowel habits
Blood, mucus, or pus in the stool
Weight loss that can't be explained
h2.text: This test can also be used to:
h2.detail: Confirm findings of another test or x-rays
Screen for colorectal cancer or polyps
Take a biopsy of a growth

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal test result will show no problems with the color, texture, and size of the lining of the sigmoid colon, rectal mucosa, rectum, and anus.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results can indicate:
h2.detail: Blockage of the large intestine ( Hirschsprung disease )
Diverticulosis (abnormal pouches on the lining of the intestines)
Inflammation or infection ( proctitis and colitis)

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done to tell if a person has abnormal hemoglobin that causes sickle cell disease and sickle cell trait. Hemoglobin is a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen.
In sickle cell disease, a person has two abnormal hemoglobin S genes. A person with sickle cell trait has only one of these abnormal genes and no symptoms, or only mild ones.
This test does not tell the difference between these two conditions. Another test, called hemoglobin electrophoresis , will be done to tell which condition someone has.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal test result is called a negative result.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An abnormal test result indicates the person might have one of these:

Iron deficiency or blood transfusions within the past 3 months can cause a false negative result. This means the person might have the abnormal hemoglobin for sickle cell, but these other factors are making their test results appear negative (normal).

picture.picname: Red blood cells, multiple sickle cells
Red blood cells, sickle and Pappenheimer

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Tell the health care provider if you are:
h2.detail: Allergic to x-ray contrast material or any iodine substance
h2.text: You must sign a consent form. You will need to rinse your mouth with germ-killing (antiseptic) solution before the procedure.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: A sialogram may be done when your provider thinks you might have a disorder of the salivary ducts or glands.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may suggest:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.

Tell your doctor if you are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious (sedative). Your doctor may also suggest an "open" MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.
Before the test, tell your health care provider if you have:
h2.detail: Certain types of artificial heart valves
Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)
Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes)
h2.text: Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed in the room with the MRI scanner:
h2.detail: Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.
Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.
Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.
Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: MRI is useful for diagnosing and evaluating sports injuries. It can provide clear pictures of parts of the shoulder (such as soft tissues) that are hard to see clearly on CT scans.
Your provider may order this test if you have:
h2.detail: A mass that can be felt during a physical exam
An abnormal finding on an x-ray or bone scan
Decreased motion of the shoulder joint
Fluid buildup in the shoulder joint
Redness or swelling of the shoulder joint
Shoulder pain and a history of cancer
Shoulder pain that does not get better with treatment

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means no problems were seen in your shoulder and surrounding tissue in the images.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Some possible causes of abnormal results may be:
This list does not include all possible problems. Talk to your provider with any questions and concerns.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Certain exams require a special dye, called contrast, to be delivered into the body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.
h2.detail: Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.
Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to safely receive this substance.
Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage) because you may need to take extra precautions.
h2.text: If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), find out if the CT machine has a weight limit. Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts.
You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: CT rapidly creates detailed pictures of the shoulder. The test may help diagnose or detect:
h2.detail: A dislocation , fracture , or other shoulder injury
Evaluate the soft tissue such as rotator cuff tendons
The cause of pain or other problems in the shoulder joint when MRI cannot be done
Healing problems or scar tissue following surgery
h2.text: This test may also help guide a surgeon to the right area during a biopsy in the shoulder area.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Results are considered normal if the shoulder being examined is normal in appearance.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Failure to heal or development of scar tissue after surgery

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.
h2.detail: Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.
DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done to:
h2.detail: Determine if a woman is ovulating
Evaluate a woman with repeated miscarriages (other tests are used more commonly)
Determine the risk for miscarriage or ectopic pregnancy early in pregnancy

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Progesterone levels vary, depending on the timing when the test is done. Blood progesterone levels start to rise midway through the menstrual cycle. It continues to rise for about 6 to 10 days, and then falls if the egg is not fertilized.
Levels continue to rise in early pregnancy.
The following are normal ranges based upon certain phases of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy:
h2.detail: Female (pre-ovulation): less than 1 nanogram per mililiter (ng/mL) or 3.18 nanomoles per liter (nmol/L)
Female (mid-cycle): 5 to 20 ng/mL or 15.90 to 63.60 nmol/L
Male: less than 1 ng/mL or 3.18 nmol/L
Postmenopausal: less than 1 ng/mL or 3.18 nmol/L
Pregnancy 1st trimester: 11.2 to 90.0 ng/mL or 35.62 to 286.20 nmol/L
Pregnancy 2nd trimester: 25.6 to 89.4 ng/mL or 81.41 to 284.29 nmol/L
Pregnancy 3rd trimester: 48 to 150 to 300 or more ng/mL or 152.64 to 477 to 954 or more nmol/L
h2.text: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.
The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Higher-than-normal levels may be due to:
Lower-than-normal levels may be due to:
h2.detail: Amenorrhea (no periods as result of anovulation [ovulation does not occur])

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: For help preparing your baby for the test, see infant test or procedure preparation (birth to 1 year).

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done to screen infants for PKU, a fairly rare condition that occurs when the body lacks a substance needed to breakdown the amino acid phenylalanine.

If PKU is not detected early, increasing phenylalanine levels in the baby will cause intellectual disability. When discovered early, changes in the diet can help prevent the severe side effects of PKU.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal test result means that phenylalanine levels are normal and the child does not have PKU.
Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your baby's test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: If the screening test results are abnormal, PKU is a possibility. Further testing will be done if the phenylalanine levels in your baby's blood are too high.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Iron level can change, depending on how recently you ingested iron. Your health care provider will likely have you do this test in the morning or after fasting.
Certain medicines may affect the results of this test. Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines. DO NOT stop any medicine before talking to your provider.
Medicines that can affect the test result include:
h2.detail: Deferoxamine (removes excess iron from the body)

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Your provider may recommend this test if you have:
h2.detail: Anemia caused by a chronic disease

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal value range is:
h2.detail: Iron: 60 to 170 micrograms per deciliter (mcg/dL), or 10.74 to 30.43 micromoles per liter (micromol/L)
Total iron binding capacity ( TIBC ): 240 to 450 mcg/dL, or 42.96 to 80.55 micromol/L
h2.text: The numbers above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Higher-than-normal iron level may be a sign of:
h2.detail: Too much iron in the body ( hemochromatosis )
Anemia due to red blood cells being destroyed too quickly ( hemolytic anemia )
h2.text: Lower-than-normal level may be a sign of:
h2.detail: Intestinal conditions that cause poor absorption of iron
Not enough iron in the diet

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special steps are needed to prepare for this test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The test is done to find out whether a person has ever been infected with oral or genital herpes . It looks for antibodies to herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) and herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2). An antibody is a substance made by the body's immune system when it detects harmful substances such as the herpes virus. This test does not detect the virus itself.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A negative (normal) test most often means you have not been infected with HSV-1 or HSV-2.

If the infection occurred very recently (within a few weeks to 3 months), the test may be negative, but you may still be infected. This is called a false negative. It can take up to 3 months after a possible herpes exposure for this test to be positive.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A positive test means you have been infected with HSV recently or at some point in the past.
Tests can be done to help determine if you have a recent infection.
About 70% of adults have been infected by HSV-1 and have antibodies against the virus. About 20 to 50% of adults will have antibodies against the HSV-2 virus, which causes genital herpes.

HSV stays in your system once you have been infected. It may be "asleep" (dormant), and cause no symptoms, or it may flare up and cause symptoms. This test cannot tell whether you are having a flare-up.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Follow instructions on whether or not you need to fast before this test.
Certain medicines may affect the results of this test. Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines. Do not stop any medicine before talking to your provider.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done to look at globulin proteins in the blood. Identifying the types of globulins can help diagnose certain medical problems.
Globulins are roughly divided into three groups: alpha, beta, and gamma globulins. Gamma globulins include various types of antibodies such as immunoglobulins (Ig) M, G, and A.

Certain diseases are associated with producing too many immunoglobulins. For example, Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is a cancer of certain white blood cells. It is linked with producing too many IgM antibodies.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal value ranges are:
h2.detail: Serum globulin: 2.0 to 3.5 grams per deciliter (g/dL) or 20 to 35 grams per liter (g/L)
IgM component: 75 to 300 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) or 750 to 3,000 milligrams per liter (mg/L)
IgG component: 650 to 1,850 mg/dL or 6.5 to 18.50 g/L
IgA component: 90 to 350 mg/dL or 900 to 3,500 mg/L
h2.text: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Increased gamma globulin proteins may indicate:
h2.detail: Blood and bone marrow cancers including multiple myeloma , and some lymphomas and leukemias
Long-term ( chronic ) inflammatory disease (for example, rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus )

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No preparation is necessary.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Hemoglobin (Hb) is the main component of red blood cells. It is a protein that carries oxygen. This test is done to diagnose or monitor how severe hemolytic anemia is. This is a disorder in which a low red blood cell count is caused by the abnormal breakdown of red blood cells.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Plasma or serum in someone who does not have hemolytic anemia may contain up to 5 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) or 0.05 grams per liter (g/L) hemoglobin.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A higher-than-normal level may indicate:
h2.detail: A hemolytic anemia (due to any cause including autoimmune and non-immune causes, such as thalassemia )
Condition in which red blood cells break down when the body is exposed to certain drugs or the stress of infection ( G6PD deficiency )
Low red blood cell count due to red blood cells breaking down sooner than normal
Blood disorder in which red blood cells are destroyed when they go from cold to warm temperatures ( paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria )

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is needed.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Serotonin is a chemical produced by nerve cells.

This test may be done to diagnose carcinoid syndrome . Carcinoid syndrome is a group of symptoms associated with carcinoid tumors. These are tumors of the small intestine, colon, appendix, and bronchial tubes in the lungs. People with carcinoid syndrome often have high levels of serotonin in the blood.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The normal range is 50 to 200 ng/mL (0.28 to 1.14 µmol/L).

Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A higher-than-normal level may indicate carcinoid syndrome.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: There is no special preparation.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Brucellosis is an infection that occurs from coming into contact with animals that carry brucella bacteria.

Your health care provider may order this test if you have signs or symptoms of brucellosis. People working in jobs where they often come in contact with animals or meat, such as slaughterhouse workers, farmers, and veterinarians, are most likely to get this disease.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal (negative) result usually means you have not come in contact with the bacteria that causes brucellosis. However, this test may not detect the disease at an early stage. Your provider may have you come back for another test in 10 days to 3 weeks.
Infection with other bacteria, such as yersinia, francisella, and vibrio, and certain immunizations can cause false-positive results.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An abnormal (positive) result usually means you have come in contact with the bacteria that causes brucellosis.

However, this positive result does not mean that you have an active infection. Your provider will have you repeat the test after a few weeks to see if the test result increases. This increase is more likely to be a sign of a current infection.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Follow your health care provider's instructions on how to prepare for the method used to obtain the culture.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The test shows which antibiotic drugs should be used to treat an infection.

Many organisms are resistant to certain antibiotics. Sensitivity tests are important in helping find the right antibiotic for you. Your provider may start you on one antibiotic, but later change you to another because of the results of sensitivity analysis.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: If the organism shows resistance to the antibiotics used in the test, those antibiotics will not be effective treatment.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: In order to have an adequate sperm count, do not have any sexual activity that causes ejaculation for 2 to 3 days before the test. However, this time should not be longer than 5 days, after which the quality can diminish.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Semen analysis is one of the first tests done to evaluate a man's fertility. It can help determine if a problem in sperm production or quality of the sperm is causing infertility . About half of couples unable to have children have a male infertility problem.
The test may also be used after a vasectomy to make sure there are no sperm in the semen. This can confirm the success of the vasectomy.
The test may also be performed for the following condition:

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A few of the common normal values are listed below.
h2.detail: The normal volume varies from 1.5 to 5.0 milliliter per ejaculation.
The sperm count varies from 20 to 150 million sperm per milliliter.
At least 60% of the sperm should have a normal shape and show normal forward movement (motility).
h2.text: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.
The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.

It is not completely clear how these values and other results from a semen analysis should be interpreted. An abnormal result does not always mean there is a problem with a man's ability to have children.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may suggest a male infertility problem. For example, if the sperm count is very low or very high, a man may be less fertile. The acidity of the semen and the presence of white blood cells (suggesting infection) may affect fertility. Testing may reveal abnormal shapes or abnormal movements of the sperm.
However, there are many unknowns in male infertility. Further testing may be needed if abnormalities are found.
Many of these problems are treatable.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You will be asked to not eat or drink anything, including water, for 12 hours before the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Secretin causes the pancreas to release a fluid that contains digestive enzymes. These enzymes break down food and help the body absorb nutrients.
The secretin stimulation test is done to check the digestive function of the pancreas. The following diseases may prevent the pancreas from working properly:
In these conditions, there may be a lack of digestive enzymes or other chemicals in the fluid that comes from the pancreas. This can reduce the body's ability to digest food and absorb nutrients.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal value ranges may vary slightly depending on the lab doing the test. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal values may mean that the pancreas is not working properly.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is needed for this test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: A testicle ultrasound is done to:
h2.detail: Help determine why one or both testicles have become larger
Look at a mass or lump in one or both of the testicles
Find the reason for pain in the testicles
Show how blood flows through the testicles

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The testicles and other areas in the scrotum appear normal.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Possible causes of abnormal results include:
h2.detail: Collection of very small veins, called a varicocele
Twisting of the testicle that blocks blood flow, called testicular torsion

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No preparation is necessary.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Testing for HIV infection is done for many reasons, including for:
h2.detail: People who want to be tested
People in high-risk groups (men who have sex with men, injection drug users and their sexual partners, and commercial sex workers)
People with certain conditions and infections (such as Kaposi sarcoma or Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia)
Pregnant women, to help prevent them from passing the virus to the baby

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A negative test result is normal. People with early HIV infection may have a negative test result.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A positive result on a screening test does not confirm that the person has HIV infection. More tests are needed to confirm HIV infection.

A negative test result does not rule out HIV infection. There is a period of time, called the window period, between HIV infection and the appearance of anti-HIV antibodies. During this period, antibodies and antigen may not be measured.
If a person might have acute or primary HIV infection and is in the window period, a negative screening test doesn't rule out HIV infection. Follow-up tests for HIV are needed.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You will be asked to remove your glasses or contact lenses before the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is used when the eye doctor suspects you have dry eye. Symptoms include dryness of the eyes or excessive watering of the eyes.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: More than 10 mm of moisture on the filter paper after 5 minutes is a sign of normal tear production. Both eyes normally release the same amount of tears.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Dry eyes may result from:
h2.detail: Swelling or inflammation of the eyelids ( blepharitis )

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: There is no special preparation for a needle biopsy. However, you may be asked not to drink or eat anything for a few hours before the test.
For surgical removal of a tumor, preparation is the same as for any major surgery. You will not be able to eat anything for 6 to 8 hours before the surgery.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done to find the cause of abnormal lumps or growths of the salivary glands. It is also done to diagnose Sjogren syndrome.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The salivary gland tissue is normal.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may indicate:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You should not move, speak, or swallow during the test. Such movements can change the pressure in the middle ear and give incorrect test results.

The sounds heard during the test may be loud. This may be startling. You will need to try very hard to stay calm and not get startled during the test. If your child is to have this test done, it may be helpful to show how the test is done using a doll. The more your child knows what to expect and why the test is done, the less nervous your child will be.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test measures how your ear reacts to sound and different pressures.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The pressure inside the middle ear can vary by a very small amount. The eardrum should look smooth.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Tympanometry may reveal any of the following:
h2.detail: A tumor in the middle ear
Lack of contact between the conduction bones of the middle ear

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: There is no special preparation.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This blood test is done when tularemia is suspected.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result is no antibodies specific for F tularensis are found in the serum.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: If antibodies are detected, there has been exposure to F tularensis.

If antibodies are found, it means you either have a current or past infection with F tularensis. In some cases, a single high level of antibodies that are specific to F tularensis means you have an infection.

During the early stage of an illness, few antibodies may be detected. Antibody production increases during the course of an infection. For this reason, this test may be repeated several weeks after the first test.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is usually necessary.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Your health care provider may recommend this test if you have signs or symptoms of an overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism), including symptoms of:
h2.detail: Thyroiditis (swelling of the thyroid gland caused by an overactive immune system)
h2.text: The test is also done during the last 3 months of pregnancy to predict Graves disease in the baby.
The TSI test is most commonly done if you have signs or symptoms of hyperthyroidism but are unable to have a test called thyroid uptake and scan .
This test is not commonly done because it is expensive. Most of the time, another test called TSH receptor antibody test is ordered instead.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal values are less than 130% of basal activity.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A higher-than-normal level may indicate:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: There is no preparation needed for this test. Ask your health care provider about any medicines you are taking that may affect the test results. DO NOT stop taking any medicines without first asking your provider.
Medicines you may need to stop for a short time include:
The vitamin biotin (B7) can affect the results of the TSH test. If you take biotin, talk to your provider before you have any thyroid function tests.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Your provider will order this test if you have symptoms or signs of an overactive or underactive thyroid gland. It is also used to monitor treatment of these conditions.
Your provider may also check your TSH level if you are planning to get pregnant.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal values range from 0.5 to 5 microunits per milliliter (µU/mL).
TSH values can vary during the day. It is best to have the test early in the morning. Experts do not fully agree on what the upper number should be when diagnosing thyroid disorders.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.
If you are being treated for a thyroid disorder, your TSH level will likely be kept between 0.5 and 4.0 µU/mL, except when:
h2.detail: A pituitary disorder is the cause of the thyroid problem. A low TSH may be expected.
You have a history of certain types of thyroid cancer. A TSH value below the normal range may be best to prevent the thyroid cancer from coming back.
A woman is pregnant. The normal range for TSH is different for women who are pregnant. Your provider may suggest that you take thyroid hormone, even if your TSH is in the normal range.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A higher-than-normal TSH level is most often due to an underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism). There are many causes of this problem.
A lower-than-normal level may be due to an overactive thyroid gland, which can be caused by:
h2.detail: Toxic nodular goiter or multinodular goiter
Too much iodine in the body (due to receiving iodine contrast used during imaging tests, such as CT scan)
Taking too much thyroid hormone medicine or prescribed natural or over-the-counter supplements that contain thyroid hormone
h2.text: Use of certain medicines may also cause a lower-than-normal TSH level. These include glucocorticoids/steroids, dopamine, certain chemotherapy drugs, and opioid painkillers such as morphine.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: There are no special preparations.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done to detect diseases of the pancreas.
The test is also used to screen newborn babies for cystic fibrosis.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Increased levels of trypsinogen may be due to:
Low or normal levels may be seen in chronic pancreatitis .

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Your provider will provide you with the supplies needed to collect the stool.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: These tests are simple ways of finding out whether you have a decrease in pancreas function. This is most often due to chronic pancreatitis .
These tests are most often done in young children who are thought to have cystic fibrosis .
Note: This test is used as a screening tool for cystic fibrosis, but it does not diagnose cystic fibrosis. Other tests are needed to confirm a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The result is normal if there is a normal amount of trypsin or chymotrypsin in the stool.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An abnormal result means the trypsin or chymotrypsin levels in your stool are below the normal range. This may mean that your pancreas is not working properly. Other tests may be done to confirm that there is a problem with your pancreas.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special steps are needed to prepare, most of the time.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The most common reason to perform this test is to see if a heart attack has occurred. Your health care provider will order this test if you have chest pain and other signs of a heart attack. The test is usually repeated two more times over the next 6 to 24 hours.

Your provider may also order this test if you have angina that is getting worse, but no other signs of a heart attack. (Angina is chest pain thought to be from a part of your heart not getting enough blood flow.)
The troponin test may also be done to help detect and evaluate other causes of heart injury.
The test may be done along with other cardiac marker tests, such as CPK isoenzymes or myoglobin .

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Cardiac troponin levels are normally so low they cannot be detected with most blood tests.
Having normal troponin levels 12 hours after chest pain has started means a heart attack is unlikely.

A normal value range may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements (for example, "high sensitivity troponin test") or test different samples. Also, some labs have different cutoff points for "normal" and "probable myocardial infarction." Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Even a slight increase in the troponin level will often mean there has been some damage to the heart. Very high levels of troponin are a sign that a heart attack has occurred.
Most patients who have had a heart attack have increased troponin levels within 6 hours. After 12 hours, almost everyone who has had a heart attack will have raised levels.
Troponin levels may remain high for 1 to 2 weeks after a heart attack.
Increased troponin levels may also be due to:
h2.detail: High blood pressure in lung arteries ( pulmonary hypertension )
Blockage of a lung artery by a blood clot, fat, or tumor cells ( pulmonary embolus )
Inflammation of the heart muscle usually due to a virus ( myocarditis )
Prolonged exercise (for example, due to marathons or triathlons)
Trauma that injures the heart, such as a car accident
Weakening of the heart muscle ( cardiomyopathy )
h2.text: Increased troponin levels may also result from certain medical procedures such as:
h2.detail: Heart defibrillation or electrical cardioversion (purposeful shocking of the heart by medical personnel to correct an abnormal heart rhythm)

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You should not eat for 8 to 12 hours before the test.
Alcohol and some medicines can interfere with blood test results.
h2.detail: Make sure your health care provider knows what medicines you take, including over-the-counter drugs and supplements.
Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.
DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Triglycerides are usually measured together with other blood fats. Often it is done to help determine your risk of developing heart disease. A high triglyceride level may lead to atherosclerosis , which increases your risk of heart attack and stroke.
A high triglyceride level may also cause swelling of your pancreas (called pancreatitis).

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Results may indicate:
Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.
The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: High triglyceride levels may be due to:
h2.detail: Diet low in protein and high in carbohydrates
Other medicines such as female hormones
Disorder passed down through families in which there are high amounts of cholesterol and triglycerides in the blood.
h2.text: Overall, the treatment of elevated triglyceride levels focuses on increased exercise and changes in the diet. Drugs to lower triglyceride levels may be used to prevent pancreatitis for levels above 500 mg/dL.
Low triglyceride levels may be due to:
h2.detail: Malabsorption syndrome (conditions in which the small intestine does not absorb fats well)

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You will be asked to undress, usually from the waist down. A transvaginal ultrasound is done with your bladder empty or partly filled.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Transvaginal ultrasound may be done for the following problems:
h2.detail: Abnormal findings on a physical exam, such as cysts, fibroid tumors, or other growths
Abnormal vaginal bleeding and menstrual problems
h2.text: Transvaginal ultrasound is also used during pregnancy .

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The pelvic structures or fetus is normal.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An abnormal result may be due to many conditions. Some problems that may be seen include:
h2.detail: Cancers of the uterus, ovaries, vagina, and other pelvic structures
Growths in or around the uterus and ovaries (such as cysts or fibroids)

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No preparation is necessary for this test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test may be done along with other tests to diagnose:
h2.detail: Fluid-filled sac in the scrotum ( hydrocele ) or a tumor in the testicle
Breast lesions or cysts in women
h2.text: In newborns, a bright halogen light may be used to transilluminate the chest cavity if there are signs of a collapsed lung or air around the heart. (Transillumination through the chest is only possible on small newborns.)
In general, transillumination is not an accurate enough test to rely on. Further tests, such as an x-ray, CT, or ultrasound, are needed to confirm the diagnosis.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal findings depend on the area being evaluated and the normal tissue of that area.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Areas filled with abnormal air or fluid light up when they should not. For example, in a darkened room, the head of a newborn with possible hydrocephalus will light up when this procedure is done.
When done on the breast:
h2.detail: Internal areas will be dark to black if there is a lesion and bleeding has occurred (because blood does not transilluminate).
Benign tumors tend to appear red.
Malignant tumors are brown to black.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: There is no special preparation for the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The test is done when the health care provider suspects that you have toxoplasmosis . The infection is a danger to a developing baby if a pregnant woman gets infected. It is also dangerous in people with HIV/AIDS .
In pregnant women, the test is done to:
h2.detail: Check if a woman has a current infection or had an infection in the past.
Check if the baby has the infection.
h2.text: The presence of antibodies before pregnancy probably protects a developing baby against toxoplasmosis at birth. But antibodies that develop during pregnancy may mean the mother and baby are infected. This infection during pregnancy increases the risk for miscarriage or birth defects.
This test may also be done if you have:
h2.detail: An unexplained rise in the blood white cell (lymphocyte) count
HIV and have symptoms of a toxoplasmosis of the brain (including headache, seizures, weakness, and speech or vision problems)
Inflammation of the back part of the eye (chorioretinitis)

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal results mean you have likely never had a toxoplasma infection.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test result.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results mean that you have probably been infected with the parasite. Two types of antibodies are measured, IgM and IgG:
h2.detail: If level of IgM antibodies is raised, you likely became infected in the recent past.
If level of IgG antibodies is raised, you became infected sometime in the past.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is needed. If you are able, tell your health care provider what drugs (including over-the-counter medicines) you have taken, including when you took them and how much you consumed.
This test is sometimes part of an investigation for drug use or abuse. Special consents, handling and labeling of specimens, or other procedures may be required.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is often done in emergency medical situations. It can be used to evaluate possible accidental or intentional overdose or poisoning. It may help determine the cause of acute drug toxicity, monitor drug dependency, and determine the presence of substances in the body for medical or legal purposes.
Additional reasons the test may be performed include:
If the test is used as a drug screen, it must be done within a certain amount of time after the drug was taken, or while forms of the drug can still be detected in the body. Examples are below:
h2.detail: Benzodiazepines: up to 6 weeks with high level use
Cocaine: 2 to 4 days; up to 10 to 22 days with heavy use
Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC): 6 to 11 weeks with heavy use

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal value ranges for over-the-counter or prescription medicines may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.
A negative value most often means that alcohol, prescription medicines that have not been prescribed, and illegal drugs have not been detected.
A blood toxicology screen can determine the presence and level (amount) of a drug in your body.
Urine sample results are often reported as positive (substance is found) or negative (no substance is found).

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Elevated levels of alcohol or prescription drugs can be a sign of intentional or accidental intoxication or overdose.
The presence of illegal drugs or drugs not prescribed for the person indicates illicit drug use .
Some legal prescription and over the counter medicines may interact with the testing chemicals and false results in urine tests. Your provider will be aware of this possibility.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.
h2.detail: Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.
DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is often done to diagnose nutritional problems, kidney disease or liver disease .
If total protein is abnormal, you will need to have more tests to look for the exact cause of the problem.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The normal range is 6.0 to 8.3 grams per deciliter (g/dL) or 60 to 83 g/L.
Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.
The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Higher-than-normal levels may be due to:
h2.detail: Chronic inflammation or infection, including HIV and hepatitis B or C
h2.text: Lower-than-normal levels may be due to:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You should not eat or drink for 8 hours before the test.
Certain medicines may affect the result of this test. Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines. DO NOT stop any medicine before talking to your provider.
Medicines that can affect the test result include:

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Your provider may recommend this test if:
h2.detail: You have signs or symptoms of anemia due to low iron.
Other lab tests suggest you have anemia due to low iron levels

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal value range is:
h2.detail: Iron: 60 to 170 micrograms per deciliter (mcg/dL) or 10.74 to 30.43 micromoles per liter (micromol/L)
TIBC: 240 to 450 mcg/dL or 42.96 to 80.55 micromol/L
h2.text: The numbers above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: TIBC is usually higher than normal when the body's iron supplies are low. This can occur with:
Lower-than-normal TIBC may mean:
h2.detail: Anemia due to red blood cells being destroyed too quickly ( hemolytic anemia )
Lower-than-normal level of protein in the blood (hypoproteinemia)
Decrease in red blood cells from the intestines not properly absorbing vitamin B12 ( pernicious anemia )

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: For more information about how you can prepare your child, see infant test or procedure preparation .

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: If a woman becomes infected with certain germs during her pregnancy, the baby may also become infected while still in the womb. The baby is more sensitive to harm from infection during the first 3 to 4 months of the pregnancy.
This test is used to screen infants for TORCH infections. These infections may lead to the following problems in the baby:

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal values mean there is no sign of infection in the newborn.
Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: If high levels of antibodies called immunoglobulins (IgM) against a certain germ are found in the infant, there may be an infection. Your provider may order more tests to confirm a diagnosis.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Remove contact lenses before the exam. The dye can permanently stain contact lenses.
Tell your provider if you have a history of corneal ulcers or eye infections , or a history of glaucoma in your family. Always tell your provider what medicines you are taking.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Tonometry is a test to measure the pressure inside your eyes. The test is used to screen for glaucoma.

People over age 40, especially African Americans, have the highest risk for developing glaucoma. Regular eye exams can help detect glaucoma early. If it is detected early, glaucoma can be treated before too much damage is done.
The test may also be done before and after eye surgery.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result means your eye pressure is within the normal range. The normal eye pressure range is 10 to 21 mm Hg.

The thickness of your cornea can affect measurements. Normal eyes with thick corneas have higher readings, and normal eyes with thin corneas have lower readings. A thin cornea with a high reading may be very abnormal (the actual eye pressure will be higher than shown on the tonometer).
A corneal thickness measurement (pachymetry) is needed to get a correct pressure measurement.
Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Hyphema (blood in the front chamber of the eye)
Injury to the eye or head

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You may be told not to eat or drink anything for several hours before the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The test is done to find the cause of abnormal growths or suspicious-looking areas of the tongue.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The tongue tissue is normal when examined.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may mean:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is necessary for this test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: A thyroid ultrasound is usually done when physical exam shows any of these findings:
h2.detail: You have a growth on your thyroid gland, called a thyroid nodule .
The thyroid feels big or irregular, called a goiter .
You have abnormal lymph nodes near your thyroid.
h2.text: Ultrasound is also often used to guide the needle in biopsies of:
h2.detail: Thyroid nodules or the thyroid gland -- In this test, a needle draws out a small amount of tissue from the nodule or thyroid gland. This is a test to diagnose thyroid disease or thyroid cancer.
Lymph nodes in the area of the thyroid.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal result will show that the thyroid has a normal size, shape, and position.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Enlargement of the thyroid gland ( goiter )
Thyroiditis, or inflammation of the thyroid (if a biopsy is done)
Thyroid cancer (if a biopsy is done)
h2.text: Your health care provider can use these results and the results of other tests to direct your care.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Follow instructions about not eating before the test. You may be told not to eat after the midnight before your scan.

Tell your health care provider if you are taking anything that contains iodine because it may affect your test results. This includes some medicines, including thyroid drugs. Supplements such as kelp also contain iodine.
Also tell your provider if you have:
h2.detail: Diarrhea (may decrease absorption of the radioactive iodine)
Had recent CT scans using intravenous or oral iodine-based contrast (within the past 2 weeks)
Too little or too much iodine in your diet
h2.text: Remove jewelry, dentures, or other metals because they may interfere with the image.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done to:
h2.detail: Find the cause of an overactive thyroid gland
Check for thyroid cancer (rarely, since other tests are more accurate for this)

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal test results will show that the thyroid appears to be the correct size, shape, and in the proper location. It is an even gray color on the computer image without darker or lighter areas.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A thyroid that is enlarged or pushed off to one side could be a sign of a tumor .

Nodules absorb more or less iodine and this will make them look darker or lighter on the scan. A nodule is usually lighter if it has not taken up the iodine. If part of the thyroid appears lighter, it could be a thyroid problem. Nodules that are darker have taken up more iodine. They can be overactive and may be the cause of an overactive thyroid.

The computer will also show the percentage of iodine that has collected in your thyroid gland (radioiodine uptake). If your gland collects too much iodine, it may be due to an overactive thyroid. If your gland collects too little iodine, it may be due to an inflammation or other damage to the thyroid.

h2.title: Alternative Names
h2.detail: Radioactive iodine uptake and scan test - thyroid

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: DO NOT use antiseptic mouthwash before this test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done when a throat infection is suspected, particularly strep throat. A throat culture can also help your provider determine which antibiotic will work best for you.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: A normal or negative result means no bacteria or other germs that may cause a sore throat were found.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An abnormal or positive result means bacteria or other germs that can cause a sore throat were seen on the throat swab.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Tell the provider if you are pregnant. Also tell the provider if you have had surgery in your chest, abdomen, or pelvis.
Remove all jewelry.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The x-ray helps evaluate:

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: The test can detect:

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Certain exams require a special dye, called contrast. Contrast is delivered into the body before the test starts. This helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.
Contrast can be given in several ways. It may be given as an injection through:
h2.detail: A vein (IV) in your hand or forearm.
Your back into the space surrounding the spinal cord.
h2.text: If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.
Before receiving the contrast, tell your health care provider if:
h2.detail: You have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test to safely receive the dye.
You take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take extra steps if you take this medicine.
h2.text: Find out if the CT machine has a weight limit if you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms). Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner.
You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: CT rapidly creates detailed pictures of the thoracic spine. The test may help diagnose or detect:
h2.detail: Birth defects of the spine in children
h2.text: Thoracic CT scan can also be used during or after:
h2.detail: Myelography: An x-ray of the spinal cord and spinal nerve roots
Discography: An x-ray of the disk

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Results are normal if the thoracic spine looks normal.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may be due to:
h2.detail: Narrowing of the spine ( spinal stenosis )

h2.title: Alternative Names
h2.detail: Computed axial tomography scan - thoracic spine

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is needed before the test. A chest x-ray or ultrasound will be done before and after the test.
DO NOT cough, breathe deeply, or move during the test to avoid injury to the lung.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Normally, very little fluid is in the pleural space. A buildup of too much fluid between the layers of the pleura is called a pleural effusion .
The test is performed to determine the cause of the extra fluid, or to relieve symptoms from the fluid buildup.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normally the pleural cavity contains only a very small amount of fluid.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Testing the fluid will help your provider determine the cause of pleural effusion. Possible causes include:
h2.detail: Collagen vascular disease (class of diseases in which the body's immune system attacks its own tissues)
Collection of blood in the pleural space (hemothorax)
Swelling and inflammation of the pancreas ( pancreatitis )
Blockage of an artery in the lungs (pulmonary embolism)
h2.text: If your provider suspects that you have an infection, a culture of the fluid may be done to test for bacteria.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: You will need to prepare for some drug level tests.
h2.detail: Your health care provider will tell you if you need to change the times you take any of your medicines.
DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: With most medicines, you need a certain level of the drug in your blood to get the proper effect. Some medicines are harmful if the level rises too high and do not work if the levels are too low.
Monitoring the amount of the drug found in your blood allows your provider to make sure the drug levels are in the proper range.
Drug level testing is important in people taking drugs such as:
h2.detail: Flecainide, procainamide or digoxin, which are used to treat abnormal beating of the heart
Phenytoin or valproic acid, which are used to treat seizures
Gentamicin or amikacin, which are antibiotics used to treat infections
h2.text: Testing may also be done to determine how well your body breaks down the drug or how it interacts with other drugs you need.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Following are some of the drugs that are commonly checked and the normal target levels:
h2.detail: Cyclosporine: 100 to 400 ng/mL (83.20 to 332.80 nmol/L) (12 hours after dose)
Sirolimus: 4 to 20 ng/mL (4 to 22 nmol/L) (12 hours after dose; varies with use)
Tacrolimus: 5 to 15 ng/mL (4 to 25 nmol/L) (12 hours after dose)
Valproic acid: 50 to 100 mcg/mL (346.70 to 693.40 micromol/L)
h2.text: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.
The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Values outside the target range may be due to minor changes or be a sign that you need to adjust your dosages. Your provider may tell you to skip a dose if the values measured are too high.
Following are toxic levels for some of the drugs that are commonly checked:
h2.detail: Methotrexate: greater than 10 mcmol/L (10,000 nmol/L) over 24-hours
Valproic acid: greater than 100 mcg/mL (693.40 micromol/L)

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: Testing is most often done to diagnose H. pylori infection:
h2.detail: If you currently have a stomach or duodenal ulcer
If you had a stomach or duodenal ulcer in the past, and were never tested for H. pylori
After treatment for H. pylori infection, to make sure there are no more bacteria
h2.text: Testing may also be done if you need to take long-term ibuprofen or other NSAID medicines. Your health care provider can tell you more.

The test may also be recommended for a condition called dyspepsia (indigestion). This is upper abdominal discomfort. Symptoms include a feeling of fullness or of heat, burning, or pain in the area between the navel and the lower part of the breastbone during or after eating. Testing for H. pylori without endoscopy is most often done only when the discomfort is new, the person is younger than 55, and there are no other symptoms.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal results mean there is no sign that you have an H. pylori infection.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results mean that you have an H. pylori infection. Your provider will discuss treatment with you.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: The health care provider may advise you to stop taking medicines that may affect the test.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test may be done if you have symptoms of abnormal male hormone (androgen) production.
In males, the testicles produce most of the testosterone in the body. Levels are most often checked to evaluate signs of abnormal testosterone such as:
h2.detail: Infertility, erectile dysfunction , low level of sexual interest, thinning of the bones (in men)
h2.text: In females, the ovaries produce most of the testosterone. The adrenal glands can also produce too much of other androgens that are converted to testosterone. Levels are most often checked to evaluate signs of higher testosterone levels, such as:
h2.detail: Excess hair growth (dark, coarse hairs in the area of the moustache, beard, sideburns, chest, buttocks, inner thighs)

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal measurements for these tests:
h2.detail: Male: 300 to 1,000 nanograms per deciliter (ng/dL) or 10.41 to 34.70 nanomoles per liter (nmol/L)
Female: 15 to 70 ng/dL or 0.52 to 2.43 nmol/L
h2.text: The examples above are common measurements for results for these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Certain health conditions, medicines, or injury can lead to low testosterone . Testosterone level also naturally drops with age. Low testosterone can affect sex drive, mood, and the body in men.
Decreased total testosterone may be due to:
h2.detail: The pituitary gland does not produce normal amounts of some or all of its hormones
Problem with areas of the brain that control hormones
Diseases of the testicles (trauma, cancer, infection, immune)
Benign tumor of the pituitary cells that produce too much of the hormone prolactin
h2.text: Increased total testosterone level may be due to:
h2.detail: Resistance to the action of male hormones (androgen resistance)
Taking medicines or drugs that increase testosterone level

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: A testicular self-exam is done to check for testicular cancer .
Testicles have blood vessels and other structures that can make the exam confusing. If you notice any lumps or changes in a testicle, contact your health care provider right away.
Your provider may recommend that you do a testicular self-exam every month if you have any of the following risk factors:
However, if a man has no risk factors or symptoms, experts do not know if doing testicular self-exam lowers the chance of dying of this cancer.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Each testicle should feel firm, but not rock hard. One testicle may be lower or slightly larger than the other.
Talk to your provider if you have questions.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: If you find a small, hard lump (like a pea), have an enlarged testicle, or notice any other differences that do not seem normal, see your provider right away.
Call your provider if:
h2.detail: You cannot find one or both testicles. The testicles may not have descended properly in the scrotum.
There is a soft collection of thin tubes above the testicle. This may be a collection of widened veins ( varicocele ).

You have pain or swelling in the scrotum. This may be an infection or a fluid-filled sac ( hydrocele ) causing a blockage of blood flow to the area. It may be difficult to feel the testicle if there is fluid in the scrotum.
h2.text: Sudden, severe (acute) pain in the scrotum or testicle that lasts for more than a few minutes is an emergency. If you have this type of pain, seek medical attention right away.

A lump in the testicle is often the first sign of testicular cancer. If you find a lump, see a provider right away. Most testicular cancers are very treatable. Keep in mind that some cases of testicular cancer do not show symptoms until they reach an advanced stage.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Your provider may tell you not to take aspirin or medicines that contain aspirin for 1 week before the procedure. Always ask your provider before stopping any medicines.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The test is most often done to find the cause of male infertility . It is done when a semen analysis suggests that there is abnormal sperm and other tests have not found the cause. In some cases, sperm obtained from a testicular biopsy can be used to fertilize a woman's egg in the lab. This process is called in vitro fertilization.

Testicular biopsy may also be done if you have found a lump during testicular self-examination . If tests such as testicular ultrasound suggest that the lump may be in the testicle, surgery may be needed to look at the testicle more closely.
A biopsy to determine whether the lump is cancerous or noncancerous (benign) may be done. If cancer is found or suspected, the entire testicle is removed.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Sperm development appears normal. No cancerous cells are found.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Abnormal results may mean a problem with sperm or hormone function. Biopsy may be able to find the cause of the problem.

In some cases, the sperm development appears normal in the testicle, but semen analysis shows no sperm or reduced sperm. This may indicate a blockage of the tube through which the sperm travel from the testes to the urethra. This blockage can sometimes be repaired with surgery.
Other causes of abnormal results:
h2.detail: A cyst-like lump filled with fluid and dead sperm cells (spermatocele)
h2.text: Your provider will explain and discuss all abnormal results with you.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is usually necessary. Follow your provider's instructions about how to prepare.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: The test helps:
h2.detail: Tell the difference between myasthenia gravis and other similar brain and nervous system conditions
Monitor treatment with oral anticholinesterase drugs
h2.text: The test may also be done for conditions such as Lambert-Eaton syndrome . This is a disorder in which faulty communication between nerves and muscles leads to muscle weakness.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: In many people with myasthenia gravis, the muscles will improve right after receiving Tensilon. The improvement lasts only a few minutes. For some types of myasthenia, Tensilon can make the weakness worse.
When the disease gets worse enough to need treatment (myasthenic crisis), there is a brief improvement in muscle strength.
When there is an overdose of anticholinesterase (cholinergic crisis), Tensilon will make the person even weaker.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Certain drugs and medicines can affect test results. Your health care provider may tell you to stop taking a certain medicine for a short time before the test. Never stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.
These medicines and drugs can increase TBG level:
h2.detail: Estrogens, found in birth control pills and estrogen replacement therapy
h2.text: The following medicines can decrease TBG levels:
h2.detail: Depakote or depakene (also called valproic acid)
High doses of salicylates, including aspirin
Male hormones, including androgens and testosterone

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test may be done to diagnose problems with your thyroid.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal range is 13 to 39 micrograms per deciliter (µg/dL), or 150 to 360 nanomoles per liter (nmol/L).

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: An increased TBG level may be due to:
h2.detail: Acute intermittent porphyria (a rare metabolic disorder)
Pregnancy (TBG levels normally increased during pregnancy)
h2.text: Note: TBG levels are normally high in newborns.
Decreased TBG levels may be due to:
h2.detail: Acromegaly (disorder caused by too much growth hormone)
Nephrotic syndrome (symptoms that show kidney damage is present)

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before the test that may affect your test result. DO NOT stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.
Some drugs that can increase T3RU levels include:
Some drugs that can decrease T3RU levels include:
Pregnancy can also decrease T3RU levels.
These things can increase thyroxin binding globulin (TBG) levels (see below section "Why the Test is Performed" for more about TBG):
Other medicines that bind to protein in the blood can also affect test results

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done to check your thyroid function. Thyroid function depends on the action of many different hormones, including thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), T3, and T4.
This test helps check the amount of T3 that thyroxin binding globulin (TBG) is able to bind. TBG is a protein that carries most of the T3 and T4 in the blood.
Your provider may recommend a T3RU test if you have signs of a thyroid disorder, including:
h2.detail: Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis (muscle weakness caused by high levels of thyroid hormone in the blood)

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal values range from 24% to 37%.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Higher-than-normal levels may indicate:
Lower-than-normal levels may indicate:
Abnormal results may also be due to an inherited condition of high TBG levels. Usually thyroid function is normal in people with this condition.
This test may also be done for:
h2.detail: Chronic thyroiditis (swelling or inflammation of the thyroid gland, including Hashimoto disease)

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before the test that may affect your test result. DO NOT stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.
Drugs that can increase T3 measurements include:
Drugs that can decrease T3 measurements include:
h2.detail: Antithyroid drugs (for example, propylthiouracil and methimazole)

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is done to check your thyroid function. Thyroid function depends on the action of T3 and other hormones, including thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and T4.
Sometimes it can be useful to measure both T3 and T4 when evaluating thyroid function.
The total T3 test measures the T3 that is both attached to proteins and floating free in the blood.
The free T3 test measures the T3 that is floating free in the blood. The tests for free T3 are generally less accurate than for total T3.
Your provider may recommend this test if you have signs of a thyroid disorder, including:
h2.detail: The pituitary gland does not produce normal amounts of some or all of its hormone ( hypopituitarism )

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: The range for normal values are:
h2.detail: Total T3 -- 60 to 180 nanograms per deciliter (ng/dL), or 0.92 to 2.76 nanomoles per liter (nmol/L)
Free T3 -- 130 to 450 picgrams per deciliter (pg/dL), or 2.0 to 7.0 picomoles per liter (pmol/L)
h2.text: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.
Normal values are age specific for people less than age 20. Check with your provider about your specific results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: A higher-than-normal level of T3 may be a sign of:
h2.detail: Overactive thyroid gland (for example, Graves disease )
Taking thyroid medicines or certain supplements (common)
h2.text: A high level of T3 may occur in pregnancy (especially with morning sickness at the end of the first trimester) or with the use of birth control pills or estrogen.
A lower-than-normal level may be due to:
h2.detail: Severe short-term or some long-term illnesses
Thyroiditis (swelling or inflammation of the thyroid gland -- Hashimoto disease is the most common type)

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: No special preparation is necessary.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: T cells are a type of lymphocyte. Lymphocytes are white blood cells. They make up part of the immune system. T cells help the body fight diseases or harmful substances, such as bacteria or viruses.

Your health care provider may order this test if you have signs of a weak immune system ( immunodeficiency disorder ). It may also be ordered if you have a disease of the lymph nodes. Lymph nodes are small glands that make white blood cells. The test is also used to monitor how well treatment for these types of diseases is working.

One type of T cell is the CD4 cell, or "helper cell." People with HIV/AIDS have regular T-cell tests to check their CD4 cell counts. The results help the provider monitor the disease and its treatment.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal results vary depending on the type of T-cell tested.
In adults, a normal CD4 cell count ranges from 500 to 1,200 cells/mm<sup>3</sup> (0.64 to 1.18 × 10<sup>9</sup>/L).

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Higher than normal T-cell levels may be due to:
h2.detail: Cancer, such as acute lymphocytic leukemia or multiple myeloma
Infections, such as hepatitis or mononucleosis
h2.text: Lower than normal T-cell levels may be due to:
h2.detail: Immune system diseases, such as HIV/AIDS

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Your provider may ask you to temporarily stop taking medicines that can affect the test results.

Uroflowmetry is best done when you have a full bladder. DO NOT urinate for 2 hours before the test. Drink extra fluids so you will have plenty of urine for the test. The test is the most accurate if you urinate at least 5 ounces (150 milliliters) or more.
DO NOT place any toilet tissue in the test machine.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test is useful in evaluating the function of the urinary tract. In most cases, a person having this test will report urination that is too slow.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Normal values vary depending on age and sex. In men, urine flow declines with age. Women have less change with age.
h2.detail: Ages 4 to 7 -- The average flow rate for both males and females is 10 mL/sec.
Ages 8 to 13 -- The average flow rate for males is 12 mL/sec. The average flow rate for females is 15 mL/sec.
Ages 14 to 45 -- The average flow rate for males is 21 mL/sec. The average flow rate for females is 18 mL/sec.
Ages 46 to 65 -- The average flow rate for males is 12 mL/sec. The average flow rate for females is 18 mL/sec.
Ages 66 to 80 -- The average flow rate for males is 9 mL/sec. The average flow rate for females is 18 mL/sec.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
h2.text: Results are compared with your symptoms and physical exam. A result that may need treatment in one person may not need treatment in another person.
Several circular muscles around the urethra normally regulate urine flow. If any of these muscles becomes weak or stops working, you may have an increase in urine flow or urinary incontinence .

If there is a bladder outlet obstruction or if the bladder muscle is weak, you may have a decrease in urine flow. The amount of urine that remains in your bladder after urinating can be measured with ultrasound.
Your provider should explain and discuss any abnormal results with you.

h2.title: How to Prepare for the Test
h2.text: Your provider will ask you to temporarily stop taking any medicines that may affect the test results. These may include dextran and sucrose. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.
Also tell your provider if you recently received intravenous dye (contrast medium) for an x-ray. Contrast dye can also affect test results.

h2.title: Why the Test is Performed
h2.text: This test helps evaluate your body's water balance and urine concentration.

h2.title: Normal Results
h2.text: Osmolality is a more specific test for urine concentration. The urine specific gravity test is easier and more convenient, and is usually part of a routine urinalysis . The osmolality test may not be needed.

Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.

h2.title: What Abnormal Results Mean
